messages: e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:46): interesting, +50 Cent

6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (18:54): annevk5: is http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom-view/ the right version of the spec
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (18:54): I somehow thought there was a bit different text for http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom-view/#dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:54): annevk5: ..
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:54): > Terminology used in this specification is from DOM Core, DOM Range, CSSOM and HTML. [DOMCORE] [DOMRANGE] [CSSOM] [HTML]
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:55): > Content edge, padding edge, border edge, and canvas are defined by CSS.
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:55): shouldn't CSS get a [] ref?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (18:55): (preferably listed in the Terminology used ... line)

6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (18:55): annevk5: anyway, http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom-view/#dom-document-caretpositionfrompoint seems to miss the case what should happen with documents without viewport
6b57ea7f33069df5914663ba9e59afdf (18:56): annevk5: returning null seems to be the only reasonable option
e9fe2a8ed6a64844a5c024b6f688d024 (18:58): good morning, Whatwg!
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (18:58): Keeps getting later
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:15): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: That's what happens as we move away from midsummer
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:21): heh
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:21): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: where are you again?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:21): I mean, that's the time I start getting productive
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:21): they move movie in the park showings from 9pm to 8:30pm in august here in Toronto
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:22): (because it gets dark by then..)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:22): You do always seem to end up pretty far North
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:22): ponders
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:23): SJC and DCA seem to be about the same for North
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:24): I've never lived much further south than that, but..
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:24): I've really only lived North for the last bit of my life :)
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:25): and YYZ is really much further south tha HEL :)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:26): You can put a bound on where 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 lives from the fact that he experiences post 10pm local time sunsets but they are currently not post 10pm
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:27): Hmm, I would've situated DCA quite a bit north of SJC
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:27): Unhappily stalkpeopleusingthesun.com doesn't yet exist
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:27): So it's a bit of a pian to work out
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:27): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: i'm using Gmaps to compare..
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:28): Coordinates  38¬?51‚Ä?08‚Ä?N 077¬?02‚Ä?16‚Ä?W
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:28): Coordinates  37¬?21‚Ä?46‚Ä?N 121¬?55‚Ä?45‚Ä?W
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:28): so, it's 1deg 30mins north
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:28): Also, surely you can calculate that off the top of your head, Dr. Graham? :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:29): This is the point where I wish I had a repitoire of rude gestures in ascii
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:29): chuckles
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:29): hold on a sec
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:30): you can use http://www.happyzebra.com/timezones-worldclock/sunrisesunset.php
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:31): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: would you have pictured the delta between DCA and SJC as more than 2degrees?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:32): Without looking at a map, a couple hundred km
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:32): isn't very good at converting degrees to distance...
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:33): Along a circumference.
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:34): well, 1deg is ~111km
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:34): so... ~150km ?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:35): just stays away from America
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:36): hrm, maybe 170 ?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:36): Or actually, along a meridian.  Arbitrary circumferences may vary a decent bit from 40Mm
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:36): sighs
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:36): are those mega-meters?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:36): people actually use that?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:37): Yes?  Why wouldn't they?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:37): ooh
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:37): interesting
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:37): I do, when I'm too lazy to type out three 0s
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:37): do you have firefox handy?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:37): My find bar has `Mat<u>c</u>h<br>case`
c63a5cfce0a1819ebbe4a19e074356b6 (19:38): is it possible to overwrite the values such as width or device-width that are used by media queries?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:38): An older definition of the kilometer was 1/10000 of a quarter-meridian.  Thus, a full meridian is 40Mm
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:38): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Depending on what you mean "arbitary circumfrences", "a decent bit" would be "by 100%"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:38): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I just mean that an equatorial circumference will be a bit larger than a polar one.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:39): Well yes, at the pole it will be zero length, right?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:39): Do I really need to state that it's a great circle?
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:39): yes!
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (19:41): Though actually... NO! Geeks! :)
e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af (19:41): Yes!
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:42): apologies to the world
ec5c2479d03104dd50cca678a2c05758 (19:45): Un saluto a tutto il chan
86123bebfedc05009c27d1ac8f8c7411 (20:02): e29be37c2febc43a0d21a1f8efa351af: no, I mean coffeescript. But it wasn't my quote

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:03): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, you have to say that it's a great circle, because latitude lines aren't great circles (except the equator).  So a degree of latitude will generally be less distance than a degree of longitude, up to 100% less.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:03): . . . I mean the other way around.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:03): A degree of longitude at our latitude is about 70% as long as a degree of latitude.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:04): In Texas, all circles are great circles.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:10): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: No, you had it right the first time.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:10): latitudinal degrees are smaller than longitudinal over most of the world
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:10): No, because moving a degree of latitude is moving north or south, and that's always along a great circle (one that contains the north and south poles).
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:10): Since when you're changing latitude, you're actually moving along a longitude line, and vice versa.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:10): Meridians are longitudinal lines.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:11): Oh, wait, I see what you're saying.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:11): Yes, and moving along a longitudinal line is a change in latitude.  Your longitude remains constant.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:11): It always confuses me.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:12): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, I just sent you an e-mail, I'd like to know what the headers say.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:12): A sphere is a silly shape for a planet, it makes coordinates far too complex
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Agreed.  Let's do a 4-torus.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:13): We should have a flat torus instead.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:13): Far simpler.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:13): Haha!  We all agree!
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:13): Well, I said a flat torus, which is actually a sort of 2-torus, but maybe you meant that too.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:13): (since a flat torus can only be embedded in Euclidean space of four or more dimensions)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:13): (a 4-torus, strictly speaking, would be a four-dimensional manifold in its own right, not two-dimensional)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:13): My geometry terminology is all kinds of inconsistent.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:14): So yeah, a 2-torus embedded in 4d so it's flat in 3d
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:14): Well, to be fair, nobody talks about these things precisely unless you take graduate-level differential geometry or something.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:14): (* Recognizable by the use of the word "geodetes")

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:16): was thinking more of a discworld (where you just need X and Y coordinates relative to some arbitrary axis) or ringworld (where you need one angular and one linear coordinate)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:17): (I suppose ringworlds are inconvenient for drawing maps though, since you need an incredibly long thin piece of paper)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:17): Are we talking a circular discworld?  Polar coords are still best there.  A square discworld can just use x/y, but you might as well get exotic and go for the torus then.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:17): What's next, want it on top of an elephant too?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:18): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: Don't be silly - it'd fall off its back
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:18): You need at least three elephants for stability
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:18): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: A ringworld doesn't need to be enormous unless you're trying to build it in physical reality.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:19): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: But polar coordinates make it hard to work out distances between points, which is probably the main value in having coordinates at all
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:19): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I know, but that doesn't change the fact that polar coords are the most natural for a circular disk.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:21): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: It still needs to be long and thin, regardless of scale, else it'd be like a Rama rather than a ringworld

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:22): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, not if it's a flat torus.  Then it's just a rectangle with opposite edges identified, so it can be whatever proportions you like.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:22): It can be a square, no problem.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:22): Rama's a perfectly fine ringworld as well.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:22): If it was somewhere in the middle it'd look silly
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:22): Also, then you can use (x, y) coordinates and calculate using Euclidean distance.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:22): It's the best of all worlds.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:23): (in multiple senses, I guess)

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:23): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Though, you still have to do a bit of math.  If you're near the, um, dateline-equivalent, it's shorter to measure across that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:24): Well, yes, there are multiple routes to the same point and it's less trivial in some cases to figure out which is shortest.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (20:24): Just put your sun right above it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (20:24): That's true.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (20:25): There's only four routes to check, and you can use straight-line distance for each.
